body: not sure I understand. These are all dev scripts, nothing is public.

Thanks for the reply!

I understand that these are just for development, and not meant to be called by end users.

Perhaps I need to open up the rpm packaging to give insight to the issue:

The rpm packaging we do is conceptually the same as [dh-virtualenv](http://dh-virtualenv.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) automates for debian systems. To put it simply, during the package build, a virtualenv is made with all the necessary packages, then packaged in a rpm. On install time the virtualenv is simply extracted to the define locations.

Since all test modules are installed as part normal pandas installation they will be incorporated inside the virtualenv. By default, the rpm macros scan for all script files inside the rpm (i.e. virtualenv) for shebangs, and add those binaries as rpm requirements for the resulting rpm.

In CentOS6 the `/usr/bin/python` gets resolved to python 2.6, even though the python in path points to something newer. Having the shebang lines pointing to `/usr/bin/env python` resolves the issue in our case.

Furthermore, I think it is good convention any way to use the `python` in PATH, for developers using virtualenv, for example.

One option would be to remove shebangs completely from test_modules, something that was proposed by member of scipy project -- in the end, wouldn't the test be run using nose/py.test whatever instead of calling them directly by the developer. But I leave this decision for you.

Please note that this proposed fix aligns the shebangs files in pandas -- majority of them are using `/usr/bin/env python` already:

````bash
# in site-packages/pandas 
$ grep '^#!' **/*.py
computation/eval.py:#!/usr/bin/env python
computation/tests/test_compat.py:#!/usr/bin/env python
````

Sami
